title: Is there a way to apply index.query first before the langchain tools kick-in?
body:
I generated an index and added it to tools (see below), yet langchain's ReAct agent ignored it.
My index (via `index.query()`) builds a better answer :-(
```
index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.load_from_disk(index_file)                                                                                                                                                    
                                                                                                                                                                                                           
tools = [                                                                                                                                                                                                  
    Tool(                                                                                                                                                                                                  
        name = "GPT Index",                                                                                                                                                                                
        func=lambda q: str(index.query(q)),                                                                                                                                                                
        description="useful for when you want to answer questions about the author. The input to this tool should be a complete english sentence.",                                                        
        return_direct=True                                                                                                                                                                                 
    ),                                                                                                                                                                                                     
]                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
memory = ConversationBufferMemory(memory_key="chat_history")                                                                                                                                               
llm=OpenAI(temperature=0)                                                                                                                                                                                  
agent_chain = initialize_agent(tools, llm, verbose=True, agent="conversational-react-description", memory=memory)        
```

Here's what it did...
```
> Entering new AgentExecutor chain...

Thought: Do I need to use a tool? No

```

title: Fix Qdrant: 'ScoredPoint' object has no attribute 'get'
body: This hotfix solves the issue described in #376. There was a bug in getting the payload from the Qdrant response. I also found another issue with getting the collection name while loading from the disk. Both are fixed.

title: Add GitHub Repository Reader
body:
Adds reader for GitHub repositories (`GithubRepositoryReader`)
- accepts `owner`, `repo` at the constructor level.
- optionally pass GitHub access token, the environment variable `GITHUB_TOKEN` will be used if it is not provided.
- `use_parser` allows it to parse the supported files by utilizing existing `DEFAULT_FILE_EXTRACTOR` such as images, videos, markdown etc. files. Defaults to `false` and it requires all the dependencies of parsers (such as pytorch, sentencepeiece etc) if set to `true`
- optionally pass list of file extensions to ignore specific files with given file extensions i.e. `ignore_file_extensions = [".png", ".jpeg"]`
- optionally pass list of directories to ignore specific directories i.e. `ignore_directories = ["examples", "gpt_index/readers"]`
- it depends on `httpx` as I used it in the `GithubClient` instead of requests (because it has better support for async requests)

It recursively fetches tree objects and construct their full path relative to root of the repository. After all the tree objects (blob's with tree_sha) fetched they are passed to `BufferedAsyncIterator`. Only `buffer_size` of tree objects fetched concurrently and stored at once, thus less memory usage during the generation of documents. (I was initially looping over the tree objects and fetching blobs one at a time but as I was testing with a large repository it was consuming a lot of  memory and it was slow. 
Generated documents contains decoded base64-encoded-string in utf-8 as `text` and file name and full path as `extra_info`

#### **Testing**

- Currently I am testing in a FastAPI environment with multiple repositories at the same time.
- I am also testing with different GPTxxxIndexes.

title: Implement Support for HyDE
body:
Using the vector store DBs with the default OpenAI embeddings as pretty meh results, because the OpenAi embeddings aren't really optimized for search. We could use HyDE to improve this, and langchain already has this implemented: https://langchain.readthedocs.io/en/latest/modules/utils/combine_docs_examples/hyde.html 

I've spent some time hacking around, but I'm not sure where the most natural place to inject this into the gpt_index flow is.

title: Add parser/reader for .mbox files
body:
- Adds parser for `.mbox` files (`MboxParser`)
    - This is useful to index dumps of mail inboxes, such as provided by Gmail ([takeout.google.com](https://takeout.google.com/))
    - Can be used as part of `SimpleDirectoryReader`
    - Supports `max_count` arg, determining maximum amount of messages to parse per mbox file. Useful for test-runs without using too many tokens.
    - Supports `message_format` arg, overriding default string formatting for messages. See `MboxParser` class for default value.
    - Dependencies: `beautifulsoup4` (to strip messages of HTML syntax)
- Adds reader for `.mbox` files (`MboxReader`)
    - Iterates through a directory reading exclusively `.mbox` files


#### Linting
⚠️ One linting error suppressed: [mbox_parser.py:66](https://github.com/minosvasilias/gpt_index/blob/ee77853376f06fe3b9310218815d34f3c96ffab4/gpt_index/readers/file/mbox_parser.py#L66)
```
error: Argument "factory" to "mbox" has incompatible type "Callable[[BinaryIO, bool], Message]"; expected "Optional[Callable[[IO[Any]], mboxMessage]]"  [arg-type]
```
Would appreciate advice on whether or not this can be worked around differently.

#### Testing
- Tested in a FastAPI environment using a Gmail `.mbox` dump.
- `MboxReaderDemo` notebook added

#### Future concerns:
- May benefit from testing with dumps from other e-mail providers
- May benefit from further params such as filtering messages by date range

title: How do we persist pinecone index references?
body:
Hi there, first of all, I'd like to say that your project is amazing and is enabling great new functionalities for my open source projects. I'm about to release a major feature with gpt-index and I have a question for you if you don't mind.

So, I understand the following is how we create an index that's stored in pinecone:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21161101/216731946-54893261-bb99-4c4e-907f-92771907082a.png)

However, how can we save and references these indexes again in the future? For context, I'd like for users to be able to upload a document and for it to be saved inside a pinecone index. Then, after the program restarts or after an unspecified period of time, I want the user to be able to easily load that same index that they created inside pinecone again, without having to worry about any of the documents and etc. Is there something possible with gpt-index to enable this functionality?

title: readers/google is causing a import path problem for google.protobuf
body:
I have been working on a new reader and I wanted to utilize the existing parsers such as `MarkdownParser`,  `PDFParser`, `DocxParser` etc.

`ImageParser` was causing a problem with `google.protobuf`. I was getting the following error:
```
XLMRobertaConverter requires the protobuf library but it was not found in your environment. Checkout the instructions on the
installation page of its repo: https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/tree/master/python#installation and follow the ones
that match your environment. Please note that you may need to restart your runtime after installation.
```

It was annoying to figure out what was causing the problem but after investigating and debugging I found the problem.

There is a file at `lib/python3.11/site-packages/transformers/utils/import_utils.py` and it checking for required libraries.

```
checks = (BACKENDS_MAPPING[backend] for backend in backends)
    failed = [msg.format(name) for available, msg in checks if not available()]
    if failed:
        raise ImportError("".join(failed))
```

and going down the rabbit hole `BACKEND_MAPPING` dictonary:
```
BACKENDS_MAPPING = OrderedDict(
    [
         ...,
         ("protobuf", (is_protobuf_available, PROTOBUF_IMPORT_ERROR)),
         ...,
    ]
)
```

`is_protobuf_available` is basically checking if the library is available in the modules.

Here is the `is_protobuf_available` function:
```
def is_protobuf_available():
    if importlib.util.find_spec("google") is None:
        return False
    return importlib.util.find_spec("google.protobuf") is not None
```

Finally the `importlib.util.find_spec` function is where I found out that `gpt_index/readers/google` folder is causing wrong `google` import  path, it thinks `google` module path is `gpt_index/readers/google/` directory.
Here is the relevant part of that function.
```
    First, sys.modules is checked to see if the module was already imported.
    If so, then sys.modules[name].__spec__ is returned. If that happens to be
    set to None, then ValueError is raised. If the module is not in
    sys.modules, then sys.meta_path is searched for a suitable spec with the
    value of 'path' given to the finders. None is returned if no spec could
    be found.

    If the name is for submodule (contains a dot), the parent module is
    automatically imported.
```
 and changing this folder name to something other than `google` solves the problem.

title: Ability to download loaders from remote hub
body:
Download and use loaders from the new loader hub. Super simple usage:

```
from gpt_index import download_loader

GoogleDocsReader = download_loader('GoogleDocsReader')
reader = GoogleDocsReader()
reader.load_data(document_ids=['1wf-y2pd9C878Oh-FmLH7Q_BQkljdm6TQal-c1pUfrec'])
```

title: Add ability to retrieve indices from a graph
body: This allows you to use pieces of the graph in a more granular fashion - you can now retrieve an individual index from a graph by using the doc_id as a lookup. This allows you to use that index for recursive or non-recursive queries.

title: Weaviate index ignores supplied prompt on query
body:
While it is documented as if you can supply a prompt to a weaviate index the supplied prompt is NOT used on query.

Instead a QueryRunner instance is created based on 
query_runner.py line 101:
```
        query_cls = self._index_registry.type_to_query[index_struct_type][mode]
        # if recursive, pass self as query_runner to each individual query
        query_runner = self if self._recursive else None
        query_kwargs = self._get_query_kwargs(config)
        query_obj = query_cls(
            index_struct,
            **query_kwargs,
            query_runner=query_runner,
            docstore=self._docstore,
        )
```
Where query_cls is a base `GPTWeaviateIndexQuery` and it gets initialized without passing down the parent index's query prompt, seemingly with no way of passing the prompt down


Repo:
```
prompt_tmpl = """
Context information is below.
---------------------
{context_str}
---------------------
Given the above context answer the following question.  Only answer "Yes", "No", or "That is not a yes or no question".

Question: {query_str}
"""
prompt =  QuestionAnswerPrompt(prompt_tmpl)
windex =  GPTWeaviateIndex(documents, weaviate_client=wclient, text_qa_prompt=prompt_tmpl)
resp = windex.query('what is the meaning of life?')
print(resp.response)
```

Unsuccessful attempted workaround:
```
resp = windex.query('what is the meaning of life?', text_qa_template=windex.text_qa_template)
```

title: Add time dimension to semantic search
body:
I would like to add a time dimension to GPT index similarity search so that it considers a time dimension in the semantic search results. The use case is to address prompts where time dimension would help. For example, if we ask the question:

What is the latest version of X?

Semantic search will search the corpus for these keywords. If this corpus contains a bunch of release notes semantic search should ideally weight more recent documents higher. Otherwise it won't be able to answer the question as each release note will contain a version.

title: Markdown parser strips headers
body:
Given a markdown file:
```
# Document concerning X

Stuff here
```
it parses simply as `Stuff here`, which is problematic because `Document concerning X` is really important context.

Looking at the code, stripping of headers seems deliberate, but it's very unclear why and seems harmful to understanding of the document.

title: Composable indexes with multiple different configurations
body:
I am trying to create a composable index with multiple Faiss indexes, but I have some issues getting the configuration right. 

Initialy I created a `GPTListIndex`with 3 `SimpleDict` which worked fine. The first config was used for the `List`and the second one for each of the `SimpleDict`. 

However, when I switched to `GPTFaissIndex` it stopped worked in the following way.

I create a `GPTListIndex` that way:

```python
list_index = GPTListIndex([faiss_1, faiss_2])
```

Then I create the config that way:

```python
query_configs = [
    QueryConfig(
        index_struct_type=IndexStructType.LIST,
        query_mode=QueryMode.DEFAULT,
        query_kwargs={}
    ),
    QueryConfig(
        index_struct_type=IndexStructType.DICT,
        query_mode=QueryMode.DEFAULT,
        query_kwargs={'faiss_index': faiss_1._faiss_index}
    ),
    QueryConfig(
        index_struct_type=IndexStructType.DICT,
        query_mode=QueryMode.DEFAULT,
        query_kwargs={'faiss_index': faiss_2._faiss_index}
    )
]
```

I was expecting that the `faiss_1` config would be used for the first faiss index in the list, and the second config for the second, etc. by the query runner. However, it doesn't seem to be the case. I am getting that errror:

```
ValueError: text_id not found in id_map
```

Which is because the `faiss_1.faiss._index` is used for faiss_2.

If I do the following, everything works fine for a single index:

```python
list_index = GPTListIndex([faiss_1])
```

Then I create the config that way:

```python
query_configs = [
    QueryConfig(
        index_struct_type=IndexStructType.LIST,
        query_mode=QueryMode.DEFAULT,
        query_kwargs={}
    ),
    QueryConfig(
        index_struct_type=IndexStructType.DICT,
        query_mode=QueryMode.DEFAULT,
        query_kwargs={'faiss_index': faiss_1._faiss_index}
    )
]
```

And if I rever 1 for 2, it works as expected as well.

I am not sure if there is something I don't understand with how the composability API works, or if there is a bug or missing feature somewhere.

I am using version `0.3.3`. I will continue to debug while waiting to see if someone has encountered this issue. I will update the doc if need be once I found the issue.

title: fix token too big issue
body: we have a fallback for trying to split big tokens into smaller ones. however it was using the original chunk size, and with extra info there's a new effective chunk size (that's smaller). modified to use that

title: use pandas as default csv parser
Empty input string causes error
body:
On certain documents when indexing them, it fails with this error: 

openai.error.InvalidRequestError: [''] is not valid under any of the given schemas - 'input'

It looks like in embeddings/openai.py there's no check to make sure the string is not empty.

title: Return pinecone index of the entry in search results.
body: As per discussion with Jerry Liu on discord: Pinecone query should also return pinecone index that was fetched in the search results. This allows to connect it with the meta data in another database.

title: performance on large documents
body:
Has anyone already done testing on large docs > 400 - 20K pages of PDFs ? 

I recently did one with TreeIndex and now each query takes around 20-30 secs.
Has anyone done performance testing on various indexes? This might be a good blog post or a nice addition to the docs.

title: Add epub file parser
body: Uses [EbookLib](https://pypi.org/project/EbookLib/) and [html2text](https://pypi.org/project/html2text/) to read and parse .epub files.

body: Hello, I'm trying to use python pickle module to generate a pickle for an index, but couldn't succeed. So can anyone help me pickle an index directly without creating a json file first. Thank you

body: To ensure requests do not fail as seen in #250

title: Fix faiss index queries
body: Closes #342

title: add reddit search comment/submission reader
body: Uses [PMAW](https://github.com/mattpodolak/pmaw) to search for Reddit comments and submissions

title: Request: allow multiple Langchain prompt template keys
body: As I understand it, [Langchain](https://langchain.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/modules/chains.html?highlight=LLMChain#langchain.chains.LLMChain) supports multiple prompt template keys. When GPT-Index is used for memory, this is reduced to one: https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/blob/f6a985241f388a9b7513ef5405025e6e2324e01e/gpt_index/langchain_helpers/memory_wrapper.py#L22 It would be useful if multiple prompt template keys and GPT-Index could be used together.

title: Faiss index - TypeError: unsupported format string passed to numpy.ndarray.__format__
body:
GPTFaissIndex returns error when I execute simple query:
```
# ------------ Get some urls from any website if url contains string features --------------------
from usp.tree import sitemap_tree_for_homepage
urls = []

def process_domain(site):
    tree = sitemap_tree_for_homepage(site) #the url of the homepage of the website wanted for a similarity search of its content
    for page in tree.all_pages():
        if "features" in page.url:
            urls.append(page.url)

process_domain("https://www.liveagent.com")


# ------------ Load urls into documents --------------------
from gpt_index import BeautifulSoupWebReader
reader = BeautifulSoupWebReader()
documents = reader.load_data(urls=urls)

# ------------ build faiss index --------------------

import faiss
from gpt_index import GPTFaissIndex
faiss_index = faiss.IndexFlatL2(1536)
index = GPTFaissIndex(documents=documents, faiss_index=faiss_index)

# ------------ Query Faiss index --------------------

response = index.query("How can I integrate live chat into my website?", verbose=True)
```

title: Update usage_pattern.md
body: change text-davinci-002 to text-davinci-003

title: Request for Document Weighting Feature in gpt-index
body:
Can different weights be assigned to multiple documents used as embeddings when querying a large language model through gpt-index library?

When working with a corpus consisting of multiple documents, prioritizing certain documents over others in the event of multiple index query matches can be useful.

Is this feature currently available or can it be added in the future?

Thanks for your time.

title: Integrate Qdrant as another vector store
body: As suggested in https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/issues/293 This PR provides Qdrant as another vector store and reader. It's still in progress.

title: A single term is larger than the allowed chunk size.
body: I am getting this error but I can not understand which document has problem. How can I debug this issue?

title: Add pandas-based tabular parser
body:
As per the discussion in [discord](https://discord.com/channels/1059199217496772688/1069324735218978818), this is a draft of a CSV parser that uses pandas for loading the CSV data.

If this goes in the right direction, we could also add an Excel / OpenDocument Table format in the same style. (And notebooks to showcase it, if that makes sense?)

I also fixed the documentation of the existing CSV parser.

How can I just pass the user-uploaded file as the value to be extracted and indexed?

title: How to solve limit rate  during `load_data` ?
body:
How to resolve following error?
```
openai.error.RateLimitError: Rate limit reached for default-global-with-image-limits in organization org-xxx
on requests per min. Limit: 60.000000 / min. Current: 120.000000 / min. Contact support@openai.com if you continue to have issues. Please add a payment method to your account to increase your rate limit. Visit https://beta.openai.com/account/billing to add a payment method.
```

I use following code for indexer

```python
from gpt_index import GPTSimpleVectorIndex
from gpt_index.readers.database import DatabaseReader

documents = DatabaseReader(
    uri='clickhouse+native://localhost:9000/default',
).load_data(
    query="SELECT concat( arrayStringConcat( "
          "  arrayMap("
          "     x -> dictGet('default.clickhouse_telegram_dict_hierarchical','text', x), "
          "     dictGetHierarchy('default.clickhouse_telegram_dict_hierarchical', id)"
          "  ), '\n'"
          "), '\n', text) AS t "
          "FROM default.clickhouse_telegram_data WHERE type='message' AND reply_to_message_id!=0"
)
index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex(documents)
index.save_to_disk('data/gpt-index.json')
```

title: added ObsidianReader data connector
body: Useful for people that would like to quickly turn their Obsidian vault into a GPT Index that they can query. Most important feature to me is that I decided to chunk the markdown files by the headers instead of by the more random chunking that is usually used.

title: Feature request - Web scrapper / crawler integration
body:
Now that GPT index supports many file formats, the other workflow that would be facilitated would be to pass URL as documents and embed their content. 
It would be even more powerful if it could crawl a domain somehow.

title: refactors: index to query mapping, composability
body:
This PR makes a few key refactors to allow indices to be more extensible in the future (say, user-specified indices).
- Removed query_map.py which hardcodes the mapping between an index struct type and the query classes. Moved this to `get_query_map` as a classmethod on each index class.
- Added an index registry, which maintains the string "type" of each index, and the mapping from type to index structure + query class. This is similar in nature to docstore, but can't be serialized to JSON as it contains class types.
- Added a "ComposableGraph" struct that can take in an already-composed index, and add higher-level operations on top of it - most notably saving to disk and loading from disk. Before we depended on a single index to not only save itself to disk but also the entire docstore. We now move this job to ComposableGraph, which will save the entire docstore collection. A single index only saves the contents of a single index to disk.

title: Can it be used without a response?
body: The GPT-generated response is awesome but for my current project, the sources info is enough, can I spare the cost of the call to GPT when making a query and just return the closest sources?
